California State Child Welfare Council Sacramento June 2009
California State Child Welfare Council
Sacramento June 2009

Presented by Kathryn Icenhower, PhD, LCSW, Executive Director SHIELDS for Families, Inc.

page.title:
SHIELDS currently has 30 programs located in the communities of Compton and Watts with a static capacity of 3000 families.

page.normal_text:
Incorporated in 1991, SHIELDS has been working as a contractor with the Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services since 1992 as one of the first Family Preservation agencies in Los Angeles.
Incorporated in 1991, SHIELDS has I n c o r p o r a t e d
i n
1 9 9 1 ,
S H I E L D S h a s
been working as a contractor with the
Los Angeles County Department of
Children and Family Services since
1992 as one of the first Family
Preservation agencies in Los Angeles.

page.title:
In 1992, DCFS first initiated attempts to reduce their high rates of detentions and out-of-home placements with the implementation of Family Preservation Community Partnerships. Since then, they have implemented numerous programs and strategies in collaboration with the community to address these issues as well as the disproportionality evidenced in the child welfare system.
In 1992, DCFS first initiated attempts to reduce their high rates of
detentions and out-of-home placements with the implementation of
Family Preservation Community Partnerships. Since then, they
have implemented numerous programs and strategies in
collaboration with the community to address these issues as well as
the disproportionality evidenced in the child welfare system.

page.title:
How the Waiver Helped
How the Waiver Helped
page.normal_text:
Prior to the Waiver (2007-2008), efforts to address identified gaps in the child welfare system and to bring to scale pilot programs, such as Up Front Assessments, were not feasible due to the lack of flexible funding. Therefore, while many of the programs were successful, their full potential could not be realized until the Waiver allowed for the implementation of a full continuum of care throughout the County.
Prior to the Waiver (2007-2008), efforts to
address identified gaps in the child
welfare system and to bring to scale pilot
programs, such as Up Front
Assessments, were not feasible due to
the lack of flexible funding. Therefore,
while many of the programs were
successful, their full potential could not be
realized until the Waiver allowed for the
implementation of a full continuum of care
throughout the County.

page.title:
Up Front Assessments
Up Front Assessments
page.normal_text:
In 2004, DCFS began to pilot Point Engagement (POE). POE is a process that attempts to engage the family as soon as possible after referral to DCFS. It also represents a paradigm shift from a focus solely on child safety to looking at the family and their caretaking ability.
In 2004, DCFS began to pilot Point
Engagement (POE). POE is a process that
attempts to engage the family as soon as
possible after referral to DCFS. It also
represents a paradigm shift from a focus
solely on child safety to looking at the
family and their caretaking ability.

page.title:
SHIELDS began providing the Assessment Component of POE to the two offices who piloted the process: Wateridge (February) and Compton (June). Working with both offices, we developed a standard protocol for implementation:
SHIELDS began providing the S H I E L D S b e g a n
p r o v i d i n g
t h e
Assessment Component of POE
to the two offices who piloted the
process: Wateridge (February)
and Compton (June). Working with
both offices, we developed a
standard protocol for
implementation:
page.normal_text:
• Emergency Response Worker determines that a child abuse and/or neglect allegation is substantiated and the level of risk is high due to mental health, substance abuse or domestic violence or a combination of these issues

page.title:
The assessment instrument used is the Behavioral Severity Assessment Program (BSAP).
The assessment instrument used is the
Behavioral Severity Assessment Program
(BSAP).
page.normal_text:
It is a computerized program that provides a set of standardized questions and assists in the writing of the narrative report.
It is a computerized program that provides a set
of standardized questions and assists in the
writing of the narrative report.

While DCFS focuses their assessment on risk to the child’s safety, the BSAP focuses on the caregiver(s) capability to care for the child, including both strengths and challenges. It helps to identify the extent of the problem(s) the caregivers are facing.
While DCFS focuses their assessment on risk
to the child’s safety, the BSAP focuses on the
caregiver(s) capability to care for the child,
including both strengths and challenges. It
helps to identify the extent of the problem(s) the
caregivers are facing.

The results of both assessments are utilized to help determine the plan for the family.
The results of both assessments are utilized to
help determine the plan for the family.

To date, 5312 assessments have been conducted, keeping over 9000 children out of the dependency court system.
To date, 5312 assessments have been
conducted, keeping over 9000 children out of
the dependency court system.

Of the families assessed, less than 5% result in detentions and subsequent open dependency court cases.
Of the families assessed, less than 5% result in
detentions and subsequent open dependency court
cases.
page.title:
The majority of cases go to VFM or VFR, avoiding the court and reducing the time the case is under DCFS jurisdiction (approx. 6 months).
The majority of cases go to VFM or VFR, avoiding the
court and reducing the time the case is under DCFS
jurisdiction (approx. 6 months).
page.normal_text:
All cases referred are high risk or very high risk and would have resulted in detention prior to the implementation of this pilot program.
All cases referred are high risk or very high risk and
would have resulted in detention prior to the
implementation of this pilot program.

Assessment and services have been provided at no cost to the families.
Assessment and services have been provided at no
cost to the families.

Out-of-home placement rates in Compton decreased by over 50% since implementation.
Out-of-home placement rates in Compton decreased
by over 50% since implementation.

The amount of time children are out of the home, reduced to less than a year (previously close to 2 years)
The amount of time children are out of the home,
reduced to less than a year (previously close to 2
years)

page.title:
With the receipt of the Waiver, Los Angeles expanded our resources in the first round of funding to provide Up Front Assessments throughout SPA 6, conducting 80-100 assessments monthly.
With the receipt of the Waiver, Los Angeles
expanded our resources in the first round of
funding to provide Up Front Assessments
throughout SPA 6, conducting 80-100
assessments monthly.
page.normal_text:
In February 2009, the second round of Waiver funding was utilized to enhance the contracts for Family Preservation Agencies to provide Up Front Assessments for all Offices and the Emergency Response Command Post.
In February 2009, the second round of Waiver
funding was utilized to enhance the contracts for
Family Preservation Agencies to provide Up Front
Assessments for all Offices and the Emergency
Response Command Post.

In March of 2009, SHIELDS trained all Community Based Family Preservation Agencies in Los Angeles County on the protocol for Up Front Assessments.
In March of 2009, SHIELDS trained all Community
Based Family Preservation Agencies in Los
Angeles County on the protocol for Up Front
Assessments.

In April 2009, Up Front Assessments were implemented Countywide.
In April 2009, Up Front Assessments were
implemented Countywide.

page.title:
Prevention Initiative Demonstration Project (PIDP)
Prevention Initiative
Demonstration Project
(PIDP)

In 2008, Los Angeles County implemented the PIDP. Community Based Collaboratives developed programs specific to their Service Areas. Initial funding was for one year only with plans for leveraging resources.
In 2008, Los Angeles County implemented the
PIDP. Community Based Collaboratives
developed programs specific to their Service
Areas. Initial funding was for one year only with
plans for leveraging resources.
page.normal_text:
With the savings realized in the Waiver after the first year, the Department made a decision to continue the PIDP with an enhanced focus on families evaluated out of the child welfare system.
With the savings realized in the Waiver after
the first year, the Department made a decision
to continue the PIDP with an enhanced focus
on families evaluated out of the child welfare
system.

page.title:
ASK: Ask Seek Knock Prevention Initiative Demonstration Project SPA 6
ASK: Ask Seek Knock
Prevention Initiative
Demonstration Project
SPA 6

ASK Program
ASK Program
page.normal_text:
ASK: Ask Seek Knock provides four Family Resource Centers throughout the Service Area. One Resource Center is linked with each of the 3 DCFS Offices in the community and one Center is a faith based site.
ASK: Ask Seek Knock provides
four Family Resource Centers
throughout the Service Area. One
Resource Center is linked with
each of the 3 DCFS Offices in the
community and one Center is a
faith based site.

ASK utilizes a collaborative model to provide three components: Direct Services, Internal Capacity Building and External Capacity Building.
ASK utilizes a collaborative model
to provide three components:
Direct Services, Internal Capacity
Building and External Capacity
Building.

ASK Program

In the Internal Capacity Building Component, partners work to enhance their own staff and agency in order to strengthen their capacity to serve families using the resources provided by the Program.
In the Internal Capacity Building

The External Capacity Building focuses on efforts to enhance the economic development in the community to provide the supports necessary for our families, including legal services and vocational opportunities.

page.normal_text:
The ASK Program wanted to ensure that families served were provided with a continuum of accessible and seamless services. To do so, we built this concept into the design of the program.

built this concept into the design of
the program.

partnerships with TimeWarner
and Comcast
ground leases for retail property; purchase of 163 unit apartment complex.
ground leases for retail property;
purchase of 163 unit apartment
complex.

page.title:
Caregiver Capability
Caregiver Capability
page.normal_text:
Parent/Caregiver Protective Factors :
Parent/Caregiver Protective Factors :
page.enlisting:
● Cooperation with Agencies/Other Helpers ● Ability to Endure Hardship ● Physical and Emotional Health ● Capacity to Form Healthy Relationships ● Positive Problem Solving Skills ● Appropriate Communication ● Past Experiences Protecting Child ● Cooperation with Agencies/Other Helpers

page.title:
Engaging Difficult Families
Engaging Difficult Families
page.enlisting:
When working with a Reluctant Family: ● Always explain who you are and your role ● Do not “push the expert card” ● Always ask the family’s perception of the problem ● Remember you are a guest in their home
